metadata.title: Fast Greedy MAP Inference for Determinantal Point Process to Improve Recommendation Diversity
metadata.author: Laming Chen, Guoxin Zhang, Eric Zhou
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: The determinantal point process (DPP) is an elegant probabilistic model of repulsion with applications in various machine learning tasks including summarization and search. However, the maximum a posteriori (MAP) inference for DPP which plays an important role in many applications is NP-hard, and even the popular greedy algorithm can still be too computationally expensive to be used in largescale real-time scenarios. To overcome the computational challenge, in this paper, we propose a novel algorithm to greatly accelerate the greedy MAP inference for DPP. In addition, our algorithm also adapts to scenarios where the repulsion is only required among nearby few items in the result sequence. We apply the proposed algorithm to generate relevant and diverse recommendations. Experimental results show that our proposed algorithm is significantly faster than state-of-the-art competitors, and provides a better relevance-diversity trade-off on several public datasets, which is also confirmed in an online A/B test.

highlights: Another method is the widely used greedy algorithm [37], justified by the fact that the log-probability of set in DPP-based algorithm is submodular
We propose a novel algorithm to greatly accelerate the greedy maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
We evaluate the performance of our Algorithm 1 on the maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
By varying trade-off parameters, the trade-off performance between relevance and diversity of maximal marginal relevance, maxsum diversification, and DPP-based algorithm are compared in Figure 4
We presented a fast and exact implementation of the greedy maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
Our proposed acceleration technique can be applied to other problems with logdeterminant of positive semidefinite matrices in the objective functions, such as the entropy regularizer [40]

We propose a novel algorithm to greatly accelerate the greedy maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
We evaluate the performance of our Algorithm 1 on the maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
By varying trade-off parameters, the trade-off performance between relevance and diversity of maximal marginal relevance, maxsum diversification, and DPP-based algorithm are compared in Figure 4
We presented a fast and exact implementation of the greedy maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
Our proposed acceleration technique can be applied to other problems with logdeterminant of positive semidefinite matrices in the objective functions, such as the entropy regularizer [40]
summary: Another method is the widely used greedy algorithm [37], justified by the fact that the log-probability of set in DPP is submodular.
Known exact implementations of the greedy algorithm [17, 32] have O(M 4) complexity, where M is the total number of items.
As shown in the experimental results on public datasets and an online A/B test, the DPP-based approach enjoys a favorable trade-off between relevance and diversity compared with the known methods.
We apply the DPP model and our proposed algorithm to optimize the trade-off between relevance and diversity.
In [18, 34, 14, 15], they proposed to recommend complementary products to the ones in the shopping basket, and the key is to learn the kernel matrix of DPP to characterize the relations among items.
We present a fast implementation of the greedy MAP inference algorithm for DPP.
Algorithm 1 runs in O(M 3) time for unconstraint MAP inference and O(N 2M ) to return N items.
The selected set of items are displayed as a sequence, and the diversity is only required within a sliding window.
We describe a DPP-based approach for recommending relevant and diverse items to users.
It clearly shows how the DPP model incorporates the relevance and diversity of the recommended items.
We evaluate the performance of our Algorithm 1 on the MAP inference for DPP.
FaX runs significantly faster than ApX, which is the state-of-the-art fast greedy MAP inference algorithm for DPP.
We evaluate the performance of Algorithm 1 to recommend short sequences of items to users on the following two public datasets.
We adopt an item-based recommendation algorithm [24] on the training set to learn an item-item PSD similarity matrix S.
DPP enjoys the best relevance-diversity trade-off performance.
We evaluate the performance of Algorithm 2 to recommend long sequences of items to users.
We construct the test set by randomly selecting 5 interacted items for each user, and use the rest for training.
By varying trade-off parameters, the trade-off performance between relevance and diversity of MMR, MSD, and DPP are compared in Figure 4.
Experiments showed that our algorithm runs significantly faster than state-of-the-art algorithms, and our proposed approach provides better relevance-diversity trade-off on recommendation task.
Potential future research directions include learning the optimal trade-off parameter automatically and the theoretical analysis of Algorithm 2
headline: To overcome the computational challenge, in this paper, we propose a novel algorithm to greatly accelerate the greedy maximum a posteriori inference for DPP-based algorithm
